title: Why are Star Trek weapons not invisible and use the visible light spectrum in devices like phasers? - Quora
tags: Star Trek: The Next Generation (TV series)

response.answer_text: Well, that's the odd thing. Phasers are presented to us as being lasers, just with the photons swapped out for a more accommodating fictional particle called a nadion. And yet if it were a laser, the beam should be pretty much invisible regardless of what frequency it's tuned to unless you happen to be directly in the line of fire. If we are to assume that the beam is something the characters can see and not just a convenient visual aid for the audience, there are a few ways I can think of to explain it. A small percentage of the nadions being emitted will spontaneously decay into conventional photons within the visible spectrum, which are then emitted in random directions. The visible beam therefore represents energy being lost to entropy as opposed to anything that does serious damage.The light is created by dust and other stray matter fluorescing and/or burning up after being caught in the beam on the way to the target. This would neatly explain the beams we see when the weapons are fired within the atmosphere or the less solid appearance of the beams in DSC and TWOK, but is very hard to reconcile with pretty much every other shot where we see starships firing their weapons unless there's a lot more air in space than there used to be.Phasers are deliberately tuned to produce visible beams due to some technical limitation of working with nadions. Gamma ray lasers are notoriously easy to diffuse, for example. Perhaps nadions are so energetic that it's almost impossible to produce a coherent beam unless you stick within the range of frequencies we can see.Phasers use visible beams as a concession to their operators, so they know exactly what they're hitting when they fire. If the beam were completely invisible it might be uncomfortably easy to accidentally sweep it over something you shouldn't, like your CO's knees.

If I had to guess it's because they are particle weapons. Ionized particles can be visible or made to be visible. And if they were not, how good would the phaser be if you couldn't see if you're hitting a target. Can you imagine you firing your phaser and you see that your enemies were not going down, only to then notice your phaser wasn't even firing because it was malfunctioning. Also some weapons in Star Trek are invisible. Remember all those times people died from radiation exposure? Most of the time you didn't and don't see the radioactive particles hitting the character. Like in Kirk case when he died.  The gamma radiation in the Warp Core wasn't green or anything like that. Still Kirk got heavily dosed with enough radiation to kill him. Weapons make sense the beams are visible, mainly because you need to see if you're shooting right. And what you're hitting. Anything outside of weapons, now that's where we can really complain.

IT’’s A TV SHOW! You need action that viewers can see. Some of the best scenes in Star Trek are the battle sequences.   From a strategic perspective, if you could not see your weapons trajectory and you missed you would be relying on your tech to tell you how far you were from hitting your target. If your tech fails, or if you are in an area of space where your targeting system cannot operate effectively, wouldn’t you be unable to re-aim your invisible weapon? While Trek did a good job of trying to stay true to science when possible, the number one focus has always been producing an entertaining TV show. That focus is how the writers invented the transporter. Having the crew board a ship and fly down to the surface of every planet would consume too much episode time. So, Roddenberry and crew invented a new technology. Presto, humans can now transport down to planets in seconds. For all the cannon and tech manuals in the Trek Universe, it is still all about the benjamin$. No TV executive keeps his/her job pitching invisible action scenes.

Why are Star Trek weapons not invisible and use the visible light spectrum in devices like phasers? In fiction, there’s something known as “the rule of cool” - basically, if something is visually cool enough, it overrides any minor details like scientific plausibility. And let’s face it - Captain Kirk pulling out a phaser and it makes a really cool-looking beam and a cool-sounding noise and the Klingon drops to the floor or disappears (depending on phaser setting) is a HELL OF A LOT cooler than he pulls out a phaser and nothing happens. Just like battles in space - it can’t transmit sound, but Michael Bay-scale kabooms are added because that’s cooler than total silence….

Because it’s a TV show. No one wants to produce a show with invisible special effects. That’s why Star Wars has lightsabers — what a pointless weapon in any kind of actually high tech conflict! Lightsabers are closest to what we call “thermal lances” and are used in warfare, but as a construction / deconstruction tool for quickly dismantling structures that are in your way, not as an anti-personnel or anti-vehicle weapon. Phasers make nice bright visible beams, not because any futuristic weapon would need or want to do so, but because the special effects budget demands it.

In star trek they what are known as directed energy weapons or particle weapons. They use charged or excited particles in a focused stream, this type of charging or exciting of particles is actually capable of being seen with the naked eye and is within the visible light spectrum. A good example of this is something we see everyday, the sun, while the sun gives off light, light is not a particle it is a wave. The surface of the sun is actually particles which is why the sun can be seen. Directed energy weapons are not light and therfore are not waves, they are particles like the ones that you see when looking at the suns surface.

For show purposes, it's for the viewer. It would be a very boring battle to see holes appearing ships and then destroyed without any drama. The technology of Star Trek should be such that the sensors can detect a hit without needing to see it. The sensors would be many times more acute than our human senses or any alien's senses could be, probably down to the atomic level. The only in-show explanation would be that there is a human need to see the results of his photon hits and destructions. We can't just accept a computer readout showing a destroyed ship.

Because it’s SciFI and they want the effect of seeing the weapon fire in the shows and movies. Visible light is itself invisible and if a Laser was fired in the near vacuum of space. What is you see as a ‘light beam’ is the dust in the path of light reflecting some of it back into your eyes. If there’s little dust as in space or clean room you see nothing as beam of light (laser or not) crosses in front of you.

Because they carry enough energy to emit stray radiation spontaneously from the beam path. They’re not lasers, they fire a (fictional) particle called nadions. Nadions can do a lot of cool tricks that photons and such can’t do. Photons are purely EM, but nadions can interact with gravity and the nuclear forces as well. They’re super cool. And one of the super cool things they do is emit just enough visible photons to look cool while doing all the other cool things they do.

One reason would be to assist in aiming. I know with our firearms we cant see the bullet in travel in most cases but when I was in the military I found the use of tracer rounds to be incredibly useful when aiming at a particular target. I think being able to see the beam, especially since phasers are mostly not aimed like guns and lack iron sights to assist in aiming, would be very beneficial to adjusting one’s aim if you missed your target on your first shot.

Because it is entertainment. If the more advanced adversary had a super strong invisible weapon they’ll shoot it in the beginning of the movie, kill all members of the other party and there is nothing left to watch for the rest of the movie. Being logical is not necessarily the best way to attract audience.

Simply put, the people in starfleet are pacifists and see no point in making weapons to kill with. The rest of the galaxy generally want to be seen as mean and intimidating with their weapons and therefore don’t care to disguise the energy expelled from them.

For practical reasons, the beam/cannon bursts/projectiles show the audience who's firing and where the shots are going. In universe, the colours differentiate the different energy types, phaser, disruptors, plasma based, Anti-Proton. Star Trek Online took that basic “rule” and expanded it for every energy type (Tetryon, Anti-Proton, Polaron) to allow visual identification of not only the energy type but specific individual effect. Tldr makes the combat more visually distinct and exciting

For purely cinematic reasons. Scenario: good guy encounters bad guy. Good guy points something at bad guy, and bad guy falls down. Now, what happened? Without some visual clue to indicate action, the views is left wondering as to what happened. So, VFX light beam, perhaps a small explosive squib on the bad guys chest and the audience is informed whats going on. Practically speaking, a visual bean serves the same function as a tracer round, for determining aim.
Invisible weapons are less interesting for the audience to watch. All else is after the fact justification.
Because invisible energy weapons look really lousy on the big screen, and worse on the small one.

Imho-Dramatic license It would be major fail if ships could not be seen firing weapons at each other. Think of the Dominion and Federation Alliance battles. Tons of ships and plumes of explosions but no directed fire. Confusing and boring. We could discuss any number of technical aspects but the above cuts to the chase. Thanks for asking.
It’s a show! You, the audience, want to see real hardware shooting stuff. A simple ion generator making a gas stream, applying 150,000 volts.. is just not showy enough.
